content.question: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge, aqueous, which is yellow, plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with B P B, aqueous, which is blue, plus H 3 O with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mtext>HBPB</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>BPB</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="8.0em"></mspace><mi>b</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>e</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>BP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, the acidified form of bromophenol blue, <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is yellow and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="440 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>440</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>BP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with water according to the equation above, producing <math alttext="H 3 O with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> ions and <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is blue and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>590 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.

frqParts.text: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge, aqueous, which is yellow, plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with B P B, aqueous, which is blue, plus H 3 O with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mtext>HBPB</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>BPB</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.8em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="8.0em"></mspace><mi>b</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>e</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>BP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, the acidified form of bromophenol blue, <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is yellow and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="440 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>440</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>BP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with water according to the equation above, producing <math alttext="H 3 O with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> ions and <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>PB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is blue and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>590 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.

The absorption spectra of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="H B P B with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B P B, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, collected at two different temperatures, are shown the following diagram. (b) Which peak, the one at <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or the one at <math alttext="800 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>800</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, results from the absorption of photons with the lower energy? Justify your answer.
(c) Based on the diagram above, is the forward reaction endothermic or exothermic? Justify your answer in terms of Le Châtelier’s principle.

A calibration plot of the absorbance at wavelength <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>n</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> versus the concentration of <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the graph below. (d) Based on the best-fit line shown in the graph, what is the approximate absorbance of a solution in which <math alttext="the molar concentration of B P B equals, 1.5 times 10 to the negative 5 power molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(e) A student measures the absorbance of a solution of <math alttext="B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of unknown concentration in order to determine the <math alttext="the molar concentration of B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution using the calibration plot above, which was recorded at <math alttext="590 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the spectrophotometer is set to a wavelength different from <math alttext="590 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> during the measurement, what would be the effect on the estimated molarity of <math alttext="B P B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain your reasoning.

Over time, <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> converts to a colorless molecule in the presence of <math alttext="O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions. To study the rate of the reaction, the student recorded the absorbance of the <math alttext="B P B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution at <math alttext="590 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>590</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a <math alttext="1.0 molar N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution. The temperature and <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> remain constant throughout the reaction. The results are summarized in the table below. Time ​(<math alttext="in seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) Absorbance 0 0.60 120 0.42 240 0.30 360 0.21 480 0.15 600 0.11 720 0.08 (f) Determine the half-life of the reaction. Include units with your answer.

(g) Explain how the absorbance and time data are consistent with a process that is first order with respect to <math alttext="BPB" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BP</mtext><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A second trial is conducted at the same constant temperature, but with <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> changed to <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The observed half-life of the reaction is longer than for the first trial when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was <math alttext="1.0 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.(h) Explain, in terms of particle collisions, why the half-life of the reaction increases when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is changed from <math alttext="1.0 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) Is the activation energy for the reaction when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, the same as, or less than the activation energy when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="1.0 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

In order to prepare the <math alttext="0.500 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of <math alttext="N a O H aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aO</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student follows a procedure with the following steps.Step 1: Measure out <math alttext="20.0 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a O H solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aO</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.Step 2: Add the <math alttext="N a O H solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aO</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to a clean, dry <math alttext="1000.0 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volumetric flask.Step 3: Add about <math alttext="500 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of distilled water to the flask, and swirl to dissolve the <math alttext="N a O H solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aO</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.Step 4: Add enough distilled water to bring the mixture to the line on the volumetric flask, inverting several times to mix.(j) Will the chemical quantities in the procedure produce a solution that is <math alttext="0.500 molar N a O H aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain your reasoning.

(k) Before adding the <math alttext="N a O H solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to the volumetric flask, the student first rinsed the volumetric flask with distilled water, leaving some droplets of distilled water on the inside of the flask. As a result of this step, will the concentration of <math alttext="N a O H solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> be greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="0.500 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain your answer.

(l) When making the solution above, the student notices that the temperature increases when dissolving <math alttext="N a O H, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in water. In a separate experiment, the student dissolves <math alttext="1.0 mol" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a O H, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in <math alttext="1000.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mn>1000</mn><mo>.</mo><mo> </mo><mtext>g</mtext></math> each of two different solvents, X and Y. Assuming the enthalpy change is the same regardless of solvent, would the temperature change in solvent X be greater than, less than, or equal to the temperature change in solvent Y? Justify your answer. The specific heat capacities of solvent X and solvent Y are given in the table below. Solvent X Y Specific Heat Capacity (<math alttext="joules per gram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) 2.91 2.53

skill.text: 2.C: Identify experimental procedures that are aligned to a scientific question (which may include a sketch of a lab setup).
